whatIsLogic.title: What is Logic
whatIsLogic.description: Logic is the study of valid inference. It focuses on the form and structure of arguments, rather than their content. Logic helps us distinguish between good and bad arguments, thereby making more reasonable judgments and decisions.
questions: How to evaluate the quality of arguments?
How to avoid common logical fallacies?
whatIsLogic.applications: Logic has important applications in many fields, including mathematics, philosophy, law, scientific research, and decision-making in daily life.

statements.title: Statements and Non-statements
statements.description: In logic, we first need to distinguish between statements and non-statements.
statements.statementsDescription: Statements are sentences that can be judged as true or false. They express a complete thought and make an assertion about something.
statementsExamplesList: Taipei is the capital of Taiwan.
The Earth revolves around the Sun.
statements.nonStatementsDescription: Non-statements are sentences that cannot be judged as true or false. They may be questions, commands, exclamations, or expressions of wishes.
nonStatementsExamplesList: Happy birthday to you. (Expression of wish)
statements.importance: In logic, we mainly focus on statements, because only statements can be components of arguments.

arguments.title: Argument Structure
arguments.description: An argument consists of a set of statements, some of which (premises) are used to support another statement (conclusion).
arguments.premiseDescription: Premises are statements used to support the conclusion. They provide reasons for accepting the conclusion.
arguments.conclusionDescription: The conclusion is the statement that the argument attempts to prove or support.
arguments.example:
All humans are mortal. (Premise)
Socrates is human. (Premise)
Therefore, Socrates is mortal. (Conclusion)

languageFunctions.title: Language Functions
languageFunctions.description: Language has multiple functions, understanding these functions helps us better analyze and use language.
languageFunctions.informativeDescription: The informative function of language is used to convey facts and information. This is the function that logic is most concerned with, as it directly relates to truth-value judgments.
languageFunctions.informativeExamples: For example: "Today is Monday." "The chemical formula for water is H2O."
languageFunctions.directiveDescription: The directive function of language is used to issue commands or requests, guiding others to act.
languageFunctions.directiveExamples: For example: "Please close the door." "Do not touch the hot surface."
languageFunctions.expressiveDescription: The expressive function of language is used to express emotions, attitudes, and feelings.
languageFunctions.expressiveExamples: For example: "I'm happy to see you!" "This is disappointing."
languageFunctions.ceremonialDescription: The ceremonial function of language is used for social etiquette and ceremonial occasions.
languageFunctions.ceremonialExamples: For example: "Good morning." "Happy birthday." "Nice to meet you."
languageFunctions.logicFocus: In logic, we mainly focus on the informative function of language, as only this function directly relates to truth-value judgments.

summary.title: Course Summary
points: Logic is the study of valid inference
Statements can be judged as true or false, while non-statements cannot
Arguments consist of premises and conclusions, with premises supporting the conclusion
Conclusion indicators and premise indicators help us identify the structure of arguments
Language has multiple functions, including informative, directive, expressive, and ceremonial functions
summary.foundation: These basic concepts lay the foundation for our subsequent study of more complex logical concepts.

points: The structure and types of arguments, including premises, inference process, and conclusion
The distinction between valid and invalid arguments, and the concept of sound arguments
The characteristics and differences between deductive and inductive reasoning
Common logical fallacies, including ad hominem, appeal to authority, straw man, slippery slope, and appeal to emotion

summary.foundation: These knowledge and skills will help you better analyze and evaluate arguments, avoid common logical fallacies, and develop critical thinking abilities.

introduction.title: Course Introduction
introduction.paragraph1: 'Introduction to Logic' is a five-day logic course designed for middle school students, based on Irving M. Copi's classic work 'Introduction to Logic'. Each day's lesson is half an hour, with content progressing from basic to advanced, gradually introducing the basic concepts and applications of logic.
introduction.paragraph2: This course aims to develop students' critical thinking skills and logical reasoning techniques, helping them make more reasonable judgments and decisions in learning and life.

originalWork.title: About the Original Work
originalWork.paragraph1: This course references Irving M. Copi's 'Introduction to Logic'. Copi is a renowned American logician and philosopher, and his work is a classic textbook in the field of logic, widely used in university logic courses.
originalWork.paragraph2: We have appropriately simplified and adjusted the content of the original work according to the cognitive level and learning needs of middle school students, making it more suitable for middle school students.

learningTips.title: Learning Tips
learningTips.tip1: Learn according to the course sequence, completing one topic each day.
learningTips.tip2: Read the materials carefully to understand the basic concepts.
learningTips.tip3: View the slides to deepen your understanding of the concepts.
learningTips.tip4: Refer to the mind maps to understand the relationships between concepts.
learningTips.tip5: Complete the exercises to consolidate what you've learned.
learningTips.tip6: Consult the terminology list to familiarize yourself with professional vocabulary.
learningTips.tip7: Apply what you've learned to daily life to cultivate critical thinking habits.
